title: Lobsters is 11 today
description:
Hey folks,

Lobsters launched 11 years ago today.

In that time our community of 16,009 users have submitted 96,480 stories, written 435,158 comments, and cast 2,882,419 votes. More detailed numbers and trends are visible at /stats.

Also, since 2017, our chat room has been moderated by 355e3b and aleph (Church on IRC). They‚Äôre now also mods on the site, and I‚Äôm very glad to have their help and judgment here as well.

Previously: 2013 2016 2017 2019 2020 2021 2022

As I say every year, it‚Äôs a good time to look back at the top stories of the year or all time, or review the comments and stories you‚Äôve upvoted. What were your favorites?
description_plain:
Hey folks,

Lobsters launched 11 years ago today.

In that time our community of 16,009 users
have submitted 96,480 stories,
written 435,158 comments,
and cast 2,882,419 votes.
More detailed numbers and trends are visible at [/stats](https://lobste.rs/stats).

Also, since 2017, our [chat room](https://lobste.rs/chat) has been moderated by [355e3b](https://lobste.rs/u/355e3b) and [aleph](https://lobste.rs/u/aleph) (`Church` on IRC). They're now also mods [on the site](https://lobste.rs/u?moderators=1), and I'm very glad to have their help and judgment here as well.

Previously:
[2013](https://lobste.rs/s/rxmopc/lobsters_is_1_year_old_today)
[2016](https://lobste.rs/s/9fcuzc/happy_birthday_lobste_rs)
[2017](https://lobste.rs/s/mazaum/happy_5th_anniversary_lobsters)
[2019](https://lobste.rs/s/cgtc2w/happy_7th_anniversary_lobsters)
[2020](https://lobste.rs/s/orrpdv/lobsters_launched_8_years_ago_today)
[2021](https://lobste.rs/s/idj3tm/lobsters_is_nine_today)
[2022](https://lobste.rs/s/jclvos/one_decade_lobsters)

As I say every year, it's a good time to look back at the [top stories](https://lobste.rs/top/1y) of the year or [all time](https://lobste.rs/top/11y),
or review the [comments](https://lobste.rs/upvoted/comments)
and [stories](https://lobste.rs/upvoted/stories) you've upvoted. What were your favorites?

submitter_user.about: Hi, I'm [Peter Bhat Harkins](https://malaprop.org), a programmer and entrepreneur from Chicago. From June 2014 to winter of 2015 I typically posted a dozen stories per day to [help](https://lobste.rs/s/9pm09z/what_is_on_topic_what_is_not/comments/nie0yn#c_nie0yn) the site reach a critical mass of regular visitors. In October 2017 I became the site administrator after the site creator @jcs stepped down. * Please don‚Äôt message me for an invitation if we're complete strangers; check the user list for someone you know or ask [in chat](https://lobste.rs/chat). * Submit a [`meta`](https://lobste.rs/t/meta) post for feature requests (including new tags) to let the community discuss. Bug reports and "is this a bug?" should go to [the issue tracker](https://github.com/lobsters/lobsters/issues). * [Message me](https://lobste.rs/messages?to=pushcx) for administrative and moderator things. I don't see everything and I gotta sleep sometime. * E-mail my first name @malaprop.org regarding site security or if you can't log in to message me. If I've posted or commented about something here or in the chat room, I'd almost certainly love to talk more about it.

Programming and computing bloggers: How do you decide what to write about?
description:
This is a question aimed at those of you that keep blogs particularly if you (or anyone else) share your posts here.

How do you go about finding interesting topics to write about?

Additionally, for the sake of discussion:

What leads you to digging into language features or discovering framework quirks or finding better patterns than what everyone else is using?

Do you do things with the intention of writing about them, or do you just write about the things you happen upon?

When writing your hot take on something, what gives you the confidence to put text to page and share it with the world?

Why do you blog at all? Is it to benefit others, to help you learn, just to document things, or just for the fame and fortune that comes from it?

How would you advise someone knew to blogging and early in their computing career begin?
description_plain:
This is a question aimed at those of you that keep blogs particularly if you (or anyone else) share your posts here.

How do you go about finding interesting topics to write about?

Additionally, for the sake of discussion:

What leads you to digging into language features or discovering framework quirks or finding better patterns than what everyone else is using?

Do you do things with the intention of writing about them, or do you just write about the things you happen upon?

When writing your hot take on something, what gives you the confidence to put text to page and share it with the world?

Why do you blog at all? Is it to benefit others, to help you learn, just to document things, or just for the fame and fortune that comes from it?

How would you advise someone knew to blogging and early in their computing career begin?

CMU 819 Homotopy type theory - Course Introduction
description:
Note that I am using the title in the first iteration of the blackboard, not the title shown at the top of the page, which is too general.

Some good quotes:

  • ‚Äútype theory is an analysis and codification of Brouwer‚Äôs intuitionism.‚Äù Around 37:00.

  • Somewhere in the back of your head, you know already, there is something peculiar about this notion of constructivism that Brouwer put forward, and that Hilbert (perhaps the greatest mathematician of the 20st century) was vehemently opposed to Brouwers‚Äô program of intuitionism, because he was mistaken. And that is the part that is not as widely advertised as the fact that he was opposed. Hilbert became such a giant in the field that if Hilbert said something, it was true, that‚Äôs it. Who‚Äôs going to oppose Hilbert? Brouwer had the chutzpah to oppose Hilbert. [‚Ä¶] Hilbert was actually wrong about some of the things he said. That has given rise to this feeling that there is something deviant or contrary or incompatible between the constructive view and the traditional view, that I have hinted at when explaining Brouwer‚Äôs program. I am going to attempt to show you through several levels of deepening that that is not the case. In fact, in a certain sense, the type theory that we‚Äôll develop is completely compatible with classical patterns of reasoning. There is no opposition there at all. But, it is very important for the purposes of everything I‚Äôve said so far, that the theory be constructive. And the reason is, [‚Ä¶] the Axiomatic Freedom of Constructive Mathematics. [‚Ä¶] The way to think about it is this: Fewer assumptions lead to stronger results‚Äù Around 43:40

  • ‚Äúif you think through what is a proof, from the perspective of a construction [‚Ä¶] you question the universal validity of the law of the excluded middle [‚Ä¶] and then, you are constructivist. A lot of people say that your friends won‚Äôt talk to you any more. Nothing you can do about this.‚Äù. Around 51:00

  • ‚Äútype theory is the grand unified theory of computation. It is what programming languages is. There is nothing else. We‚Äôre just studying type theory. Eventually all the arbitrary programming languages are going to be swept away with the oceans. We will have the permanence of constructive intuitionistic type theory as the master theory of computation, without doubt in my mind. [‚Ä¶] Working in anything else is a waste of time‚Äù. Around 52:00
description_plain:
Note that I am using the title in the first iteration of the blackboard, not the title shown at the top of the page, which is too general.

Some good quotes:

* "type theory is an analysis and codification of Brouwer's intuitionism." Around 37:00.

* Somewhere in the back of your head, you know already, there is something peculiar about this notion of constructivism that Brouwer put forward, and that Hilbert (perhaps the greatest mathematician of the 20st century) was vehemently opposed to Brouwers' program of intuitionism, because he was mistaken. And that is the part that is not as widely advertised as the fact that he was opposed. Hilbert became such a giant in the field that if Hilbert said something, it was true, that's it. Who's going to oppose Hilbert? Brouwer had the chutzpah to oppose Hilbert. [...] Hilbert was actually wrong about some of the things he said. That has given rise to this feeling that there is something deviant or contrary or incompatible between the constructive view and the traditional view, that I have hinted at when explaining Brouwer's program. I am going to attempt to show you through several levels of deepening that that is not the case. In fact, in a certain sense, the type theory that we'll develop is completely compatible with classical patterns of reasoning. There is no opposition there at all. But, it is very important for the purposes of everything I've said so far, that the theory be constructive. And the reason is, [...] the Axiomatic Freedom of Constructive Mathematics. [...] The way to think about it is this: Fewer assumptions lead to stronger results" Around 43:40

* "if you think through what is a proof, from the perspective of a construction [...] you question the universal validity of the law of the excluded middle [...] and then, you are constructivist. A lot of people say that your friends won't talk to you any more. Nothing you can do about this.". Around 51:00

* "type theory is the grand unified theory of computation. It is what programming languages *is*. There is nothing else. We're just studying type theory. Eventually all the arbitrary programming languages are going to be swept away with the oceans. We will have the permanence of constructive intuitionistic type theory as the master theory of computation, without doubt in my mind. [...] Working in anything else is a waste of time". Around 52:00
